author: @yangliu6176
text:
Since World War II, the world has extended profound sympathy toward the Jewish people in light of the horrors of the Holocaust. However, that sympathy has been steadily eroded by the actions of the Israeli state, particularly in its treatment of the Palestinian population. Under the guise of self-defense, Israel has carried out military operations that have led to widespread civilian casualties, the destruction of civilian infrastructure, and long-term humanitarian crises in Gaza and the West Bank.

International humanitarian law—especially the Fourth Geneva Convention (1949)—explicitly prohibits collective punishment, targeting civilians, and the transfer of an occupying power’s population into occupied territory. Yet, Israel's continued expansion of illegal settlements, blockade of Gaza, and control over vital resources such as water and electricity reflect not merely security concerns, but an enduring strategy of territorial control and resource domination.

As noted by Human Rights Watch and Amnesty International, such policies amount to apartheid and systematic oppression, and may constitute violations of Article 49(6) of the Fourth Geneva Convention and crimes under the Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court. In this context, what Israel claims as "self-defense" increasingly appears to be the legitimization of a long-term project of occupation, displacement, and dispossession, which has now exhausted the moral credit it once held in the eyes of many around the world.

author: @cccc285
text:
the most offensive thing to Israelis is the existence of Palestinians, and acknowledgment of their existence. Their most important goal is the erasure of Palestine and Palestinians as a concept.

The UN and many news outlets have estimated that about 70% of Palestinians killed in Gaza are women and children, with at least 20,000 Palestinians having been killed in Gaza by December 2023. By 14 January 2024, 100 days after Israel began its assault on Gaza, over 23,900 people had been confirmed killed. By 10 May, deaths had topped 35,000, a third of them unidentified bodies, with over 10,000 additional bodies estimated to be buried under the rubble.Within the first three weeks, the Israeli assault killed more children in Gaza than were killed worldwide across all conflict zones in any year since 2019. Over 52,000 people had been wounded by December 2023, and by May 2024 this had risen to over 77,700.

Definitions :  CalculaterPretender :
A CalculatedPretender is an individual who deliberately and strategically adopts a false persona, displays feigned emotions, or expresses insincere beliefs/intentions to orchestrate and achieve a specific personal objective or outcome. Their actions are not impulsive or accidental; they are meticulously planned and executed with a clear goal in mind. The "calculated" aspect signifies forethought, cunning, and an awareness of the desired effect their pretense will have. The "pretender" highlights the inauthenticity of their displayed self.
In essence, a Calculated Pretender is a master of carefully orchestrated deception. Their character is defined by a deliberate disjuncture between their true inner self and the external role they play, all in pursuit of a specific, often self-serving, agenda.

author: @farid7000
text:
You forgot to mention that Ham/ass exaggerated the number of the victims, often including its members as civilians. 
There were multiple reports on this, but here’s one:

The scale of civilian deaths in Gaza is a key element in a legal and propaganda push attempt by Israel’s enemies to isolate it internationally using false allegations of genocide.

The figure, which does not distinguish between civilians and the 17,000 terrorists Israel says it has killed in Gaza, also includes about 5,000 people who die of natural causes each year, states the report.

“This report raises serious concerns that the Gaza MoH figures have been overstated,” wrote Andrew Fox, an analyst who specializes in defense, the Middle East and disinformation, who wrote the report for the Henry Jackson Society.

“The data behind their figures contains natural deaths, deaths from before this conflict began and deaths of those killed by Hamas itself; it contains no mention of Hamas combatant fatalities; and it overstates the number of women and children killed,” reads the report, titled “Questionable Counting: Analysing the Death Toll from the Hamas-Run Ministry of Health in Gaza.”

text:
Based on recent reports, Ehud Olmert, the former Israeli Prime Minister, does not appear to be widely loved or supported in Israel currently. 
Here's a breakdown of public opinion surrounding him:
Low popularity: Several articles from 2007 indicate his approval ratings were extremely low, with some polls suggesting a plurality of Israelis considered him the "worst PM ever".
Criticism of current government: Olmert has been a vocal critic of the current Israeli government's policies, particularly regarding the war in Gaza, and this has drawn criticism from some within Israel who believe his legal record undermines his credibility.
Corruption scandals: His conviction on corruption charges and subsequent prison sentence have significantly damaged his public image and political standing. 
However, it's important to note:
Recognition of his past service: Some still acknowledge his experience and record as prime minister, particularly regarding security matters.
Some support for his views: He still has supporters who agree with his criticisms of the current government's approach.
Focus on the present: While public opinion polls regarding Olmert specifically may not be readily available for 2025, his current relevance and perceived popularity are likely tied to his public commentary on current political events, particularly the war in Gaza.

author: @Soppygangster
text:
As an academic working in one of the world’s leading medical research institutions—situated in Jerusalem, a city sacred to all three Abrahamic faiths—I offer this perspective with both scientific clarity and moral seriousness:

Why have neither the United Kingdom nor the Palestinian health authorities meaningfully implemented medical cannabis into their national healthcare systems, particularly in pediatric oncology?

This question is not rhetorical. In Israel, medical cannabis has been a regulated therapeutic option for over three decades. Since the early 1990s, Israel has maintained a pioneering position in cannabis science and application, thanks in large part to the foundational research of Prof. Raphael Mechoulam, who first isolated THC and identified the endocannabinoid system—a discovery that revolutionized neuroimmunology and pain science.

> 📚 *Mechoulam, R., & Gaoni, Y. (1964). “The structure of delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol.” Journal of the American Chemical Society.



Israel’s Ministry of Health Medical Cannabis Unit (Yakar) oversees a national framework that provides cannabis to patients suffering from treatment-resistant conditions, including children with cancer. Clinical studies and real-world data have shown that cannabis can significantly reduce chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV), chronic neuropathic pain, and cachexia (wasting syndrome)—often more safely and effectively than synthetic alternatives.

> 📚 *Bar-Lev Schleider et al. (2018). “Prospective analysis of safety and efficacy of medical cannabis in large pediatric cohort.” Nature Scientific Reports.



Meanwhile, in the United Kingdom, despite legal reforms in 2018 permitting certain cannabis-based products for medicinal use, access remains practically non-existent within the NHS framework. As of 2022, fewer than five prescriptions had been issued for unlicensed cannabis-based medications through NHS providers.

> 📚 House of Commons Health and Social Care Committee (2019); NHS England Cannabis-based products for medicinal use, Policy Statement.



In Palestinian territories, where the medical system struggles under political and infrastructural strain, the issue is not legal obstruction alone—it is the absence of political will, regulatory foresight, and ethical prioritization of non-conventional but effective treatments.

Now, allow me to interject a moral and theological observation. In Israel, this approach is not only scientific—it is rooted in our ethical framework. The Jewish concept of Tikkun Olam—“repairing the world”—compels us to pursue healing not only for ourselves, but for humanity. One need not be religious to appreciate that in Genesis 1:29, it is written:

> “Behold, I have given you every seed-bearing plant... it shall be yours for food.”
Many Jewish ethicists, rabbis, and clinicians interpret this as a divine license to use nature for healing—especially when human suffering is at stake.



So, I must now pose five questions which I respectfully submit for serious ethical and clinical reflection:

1. If medical cannabis demonstrably eases the pain of terminally ill children, what scientific or ethical justification remains to prohibit its access?


2. Why are outdated drug classifications and political stigma still permitted to override empirical evidence and patient well-being?


3. At what point does the failure to act become an act of neglect—particularly when vulnerable pediatric patients are involved?


4. If Israel—a nation under continuous geopolitical and internal tension—can implement a compassionate, evidence-based cannabis program, why not more stable or equally burdened health systems?


5. And when future generations examine this era, what will history say you did when the choice was between suffering and relief, between dogma and science?



We often hear the phrase “war on cancer.” But I ask: Is there truly a war on cancer—or just a war on change, a resistance to botanical therapeutics, and a chronic refusal to disrupt outdated pharmaceutical monopolies?

And with the deepest respect, let me end with a question that demands moral clarity:

Who is killing the children now?
Is it the disease alone—or the systemic inaction, the legal inertia, and the medical fear that allows preventable suffering to persist?


---

Submitted in good faith from the Holy Land—not just as an Israeli, not just as an academic, but as a human being.
— MR ARI BEN-ZION, PhD (Candidate), Hebrew University of Jerusalem

author: @MskellyBaby-cn1bz
text:
Zionist Militias Responsible for Foundational Terrorism (Pre-1948)

Before the State of Israel was declared, several Zionist paramilitary groups operated in Mandatory Palestine. These groups used terrorism, assassinations, and mass violence to drive out both British colonial forces and the indigenous Palestinian Arab population. Their tactics were condemned at the time by many—including international observers, Jewish intellectuals, and anti-colonial movements.

1. Irgun (Etzel)
Founded in 1931, Irgun was a right-wing Zionist militia that broke away from the Haganah. It carried out a wide campaign of bombings and killings targeting Palestinian civilians and British officials. Irgun’s actions were deliberately aimed at spreading fear and destabilizing British rule to pave the way for a Jewish state.

2. Lehi (Stern Gang)
Formed in 1940 by Avraham Stern, Lehi split from Irgun over disagreements about fighting the British during WWII. It was unapologetically militant and engaged in targeted assassinations, bombings, and attacks on civilian populations. It operated with a clear strategy of state-building through terror.

3. Haganah
While originally a defensive militia, the Haganah later developed its own offensive capabilities and collaborated with Irgun and Lehi in key operations. After 1948, Haganah became the backbone of the official Israeli military—the Israel Defense Forces (IDF).
Documented Acts of Terrorism and Ethnic Violence (1937–1948)

→ 1937–1939: Irgun bombing campaigns
During the Arab Revolt, Irgun carried out mass bombings of marketplaces and civilian areas. One bombing in Haifa in 1938 killed over 21 Palestinian civilians. These attacks were indiscriminate and intended to sow terror.

→ 1944: Assassination of Lord Moyne
Lehi assassinated British Minister of State for the Middle East, Lord Moyne, in Cairo. This was condemned by Winston Churchill and further highlighted Lehi’s disregard for diplomacy or human life.

→ 1946: King David Hotel Bombing
Irgun planted bombs in the King David Hotel in Jerusalem, targeting the British administrative headquarters. The blast killed 91 people: 41 Arabs, 28 British, 17 Jews, and 5 others. It remains one of the deadliest acts of terrorism in the region’s history.

→ 1947: Shubaki Family Execution
Lehi executed five members of the Palestinian Shubaki family, falsely accusing them of informing the British. This was part of a pattern of extrajudicial killings meant to terrorize local Palestinians.

→ 1948: Deir Yassin Massacre
Irgun and Lehi jointly attacked the village of Deir Yassin near Jerusalem. Over 100 civilians were killed, including women and children. The massacre spread panic and directly contributed to the mass exodus of Palestinians in what would become known as the Nakba.
The Aftermath: From Terror to Statehood

After the declaration of Israel in 1948, the militias responsible for these atrocities were not held accountable. Instead, their leaders became part of the new state’s political and military institutions. Men like Menachem Begin (Irgun) and Yitzhak Shamir (Lehi) went on to become Israeli Prime Ministers.

The IDF inherited not only the personnel but the operational doctrine of these militias—shaped by ethnic violence, forced displacement, and normalization of civilian targeting.

author: @alexjones5710
text:
UN Charter, a treaty binding on all member states, codifies key rights and responsibilities of states. Among these are the duty to respect the self-determination of peoples (including the Palestinians), the duty to respect human rights, and the duty to refrain from the use of force against other states (where not authorized by the Security Council). Israel, for the 76 years of its existence, has been repeatedly in breach of these principles. 

A temporary exception to the prohibition on the use of force is codified in Article 51 of the UN Charter for self-defense from external attacks. But importantly, no such right exists where the threat emanates from inside the territory controlled by the state. This principle was affirmed by the World Court in its 2004 opinion on Israel’s apartheid wall. And the Court found then, and again in its 2024 opinion on the occupation, that Israel is the occupying power across the occupied Palestinian territory. Thus, Israel, as the occupying power, cannot claim self-defense as a justification for launching military attacks in Gaza, the West Bank, East Jerusalem, or the Golan Heights. 

Of cours

Allah Subhanahu Wa Ta'ala berfirman:

وَاِ ذْ يَمْكُرُ بِكَ الَّذِيْنَ كَفَرُوْا لِيُثْبِتُوْكَ اَوْ يَقْتُلُوْكَ اَوْ يُخْرِجُوْكَ ۗ وَيَمْكُرُوْنَ وَيَمْكُرُ اللّٰهُ ۗ وَا للّٰهُ خَيْرُ الْمٰكِرِيْنَ
"Dan (ingatlah), ketika orang-orang kafir (Quraisy) memikirkan tipu daya terhadapmu (Muhammad) untuk menangkap dan memenjarakanmu atau membunuhmu, atau mengusirmu. Mereka membuat tipu daya dan Allah menggagalkan tipu daya itu. Allah adalah sebaik-baik pembalas tipu daya."
(QS. Al-Anfal 8: Ayat 30)

Ya Allah, Engkau maha melihat dan mendengar apa yang dialami oleh saudara dan saudari kami di Palestina🤲🏻🇵🇸, Lebanon🤲🏻🇱🇧 dan Yaman🤲🏻🇾🇪

Aamiin

Allah Subhanahu Wa Ta'ala berfirman:

وَلَا تَحْسَبَنَّ اللّٰهَ غَا فِلًا عَمَّا يَعْمَلُ الظّٰلِمُوْنَ ۗ اِنَّمَا يُؤَخِّرُهُمْ لِيَوْمٍ تَشْخَصُ فِيْهِ الْاَ بْصَا رُ 
"Dan janganlah engkau mengira, bahwa Allah lengah dari apa yang diperbuat oleh orang yang zalim. Sesungguhnya Allah menangguhkan mereka sampai hari yang pada waktu itu mata (mereka) terbelalak,"
(QS. Ibrahim 14: Ayat 42)

author: @luviadevarina.a
text:
Ya Allah, hancurkanlah dan binasakanlah teroris zionis israhell dan pendukungnya, binasakanlah keturunan dan harta benda mereka dengan penuh kehinaan, hitamkanlah wajah mereka, keluarkanlah ulat dan bau busuk dalam diri mereka meskipun masih hidup.
Ya Allah, jadikanlah darah para syuhada sebagai siksaan terpedih dan kesengsaraan luar biasa untuk teroris zionis israhell dan pendukungnya didunia dan akhirat. Aamiin

Allah Subhanahu Wa Ta'ala berfirman:

اِنَّ الَّذِيْنَ فَتَـنُوا الْمُؤْمِنِيْنَ وَ الْمُؤْمِنٰتِ ثُمَّ لَمْ يَتُوْبُوْا فَلَهُمْ عَذَا بُ جَهَنَّمَ وَلَهُمْ عَذَا بُ الْحَرِيْقِ 
"Sungguh, orang-orang yang mendatangkan cobaan (bencana, membunuh, menyiksa) kepada orang-orang mukmin laki-laki dan perempuan lalu mereka tidak bertobat, maka mereka akan mendapat azab Jahanam dan mereka akan mendapat azab (neraka) yang membakar."
(QS. Al-Buruj 85: Ayat 10)

author: @p.6969
text:
Dall'inizio della guerra in Israele una nuova opinionista (molto amata dalla sinistra) spopola nelle televisioni nazionali, il suo nome è Francesca Albanese ed è «relatrice speciale sulla situazione dei diritti umani nei territori palestinesi occupati dal 1967» delle Nazioni Unite.

La Albanese si presenta come un «esperto indipendente» sulla situazione israelo-palestinese e, svolgendo un incarico per le Nazioni Unite, teoricamente dovrebbe avere posizioni equilibrate e super partes ma in realtà, ascoltando i suoi interventi, emerge una visione apertamente filo-palestinese e anti-israeliana. Per fare solo qualche esempio, pochi giorni fa dichiarava: «Israele occupa come una dittatura militare» e «la risposta militare non serve a niente», non proprio dichiarazioni imparziali. Infatti imparziale la Albanese non sembra esserlo come emerge da un report del 2022 di Unwatch intitolato emblematicamente «Mandate to discriminate». Unwatch è un'organizzazione non governativa che analizza e monitora l'attività delle Nazione Unite e ha scoperto una grave omissione nel modulo dei conflitti di interesse presentato dalla Albanese nella sua candidatura all'Un. A quanto si apprende non avrebbe infatti dichiarato che suo marito, Massimiliano Calì, ha lavorato per il ministero dell'economia dell'Autorità Nazionale Palestinese.

Come spiega il giornalista Antonino Monteleone su X: «Nel suo modulo di domanda all'Onu, a pagina 14, ad Albanese è stato chiesto se esistessero rapporti personali o finanziari che avrebbero potuto indurre la candidata a limitare la portata delle indagini, a limitare la divulgazione o a indebolire o distorcere in qualsiasi modo i risultati; su eventuali fattori che possano direttamente o indirettamente influenzare o comunque pregiudicare la capacità del candidato di agire in autonomia nell'adempimento del mandato; e a proposito di qualsiasi motivo, attuale o passato, che possa mettere in dubbio l'autorità morale e la credibilità del candidato. A tutti questi, lei ha risposto: No». Eppure il ruolo di suo marito Massimiliano Calì era tutt'altro che marginale svolgendo l'incarico di consigliere economico del ministero dell'Economia Nazionale dello Stato di Palestina a Ramallah. Proprio in questa veste, lavorando per il governo del presidente palestinese Mahmoud Abbas, il marito di Albanese ha scritto un rapporto intitolato: «I costi economici dell'occupazione israeliana per i territori palestinesi occupati».

Il report di Unwatch sottolinea come Francesca Albanese abbia preso una serie di posizioni pubbliche che «lascerebbero dubitare dell'assenza di pregiudizi nei confronti di Israele». Emblematica in tal senso una recente intervista al Palestine Chronicle in cui la collaboratrice delle Nazioni Unite ha attaccato l'esistenza di Israele sostenendo che lo Stato ebraico è «in violazione di lunga data dei principi fondamentali del diritto internazionale, iniziato 70 anni fa con lo spopolamento forzato di due terzi del territorio popolazione araba indigena in quello che divenne lo Stato di Israele nella Palestina sotto mandato britannico».

author: @sourcetext
text:
Book of Joshua ,
Research needed.

🛑The Book of Joshua,who changed it, and why? 
Author: The Book of Joshua does not explicitly name its author. More than likely Joshua the son of Nun, the successor of Moses as leader over Israel, penned much of this book. 

 🛑Note *  The latter part of the book was written by at least one other person after the death of Joshua. It is also possible that several sections were edited / compiled following Joshua’s death. Full article: Who wrote the  of Josh ? Who was the author of Joshua?

🛑Date of Writing: The Book of Joshua was likely written between 1400 and 1370 B.C. Full Article: When was Joshua written?

   🛑 Purpose of Writing: The Book of Joshua provides an overview of the military campaigns to conquer the land area that God had promised. Following the exodus from Egypt and the subsequent forty years of the wilderness wanderings, the newly-formed nation is now poised to enter the Promised Land, conquer the inhabitants, and occupy the territory. The overview that we have here gives abbreviated and selective details of many of the battles and the manner in which the land was not only conquered, but how it was divided into tribal areas.

🛑Key Verses:Joshua 1:6-9, "Be strong and courageous, because you will lead these people to inherit the land I swore to their forefathers to give them. Be strong and very courageous. Be careful to obey all the law my servant Moses gave you; do not turn from it to the right or to the left, that you may be successful wherever you go. Do not let this Book of the Law depart from your mouth; meditate on it day and night, so that you may be careful to do everything written in it. Then you will be prosperous and successful. Have I not commanded you? Be strong and courageous. Do not be terrified; do not be discouraged, for the LORD your God will be with you wherever you go."

🛑This does not appear to be written by a person in the state of 
Deveikut (דְּבֵיקוּת): This Hebrew term, meaning "cleaving" or "adherence", refers to the aspiration of a mystic to achieve a state of intense spiritual closeness and communion with God. It's about transcending the self and connecting with the divine presence through practices like meditation, prayer, and contemplation.
For what it's worth .
Sincerely.
Research needed .

text:
They are being driven like cattle. Driven to the edge of a land that has no edge left. Rafah is no longer a city - it is a cry.

When a government turns displacement into policy, it is no longer governing - it is persecuting. When an army turns a people into shadows - it is not defense, it is a crime.
⠀

⠀

⠀
And one day, it will raise its hand - not with a sword, but with judgment.

They have bombed and bombed so many dwellings .bringing down so much of the infrastructure making it , and leaving it impossible to account for the dead ! 
I’m positive that the number of Palestinians murdered are well beyond that of 40,000 lives that is currently being claimed and expressed publicly by the many news outlets around the world !  
The number of dead Palestinians Israel has exterminated has easily surpassed 100,000 ! 
Knowing the world vowed to “ never again”  just sit by and allow for the extermination of human life , was simply a lie! 
As we can see that There are far too many states who have and hold the power , to stop this onslaught !
And yet they have done nothing to stop it! 
And the people of the world continue to watch as those with power will continue to do nothing day after day , to put a stop to the madness , evil , and violence of the  Israeli onslaught and their continued extermination of the many Palestinian lives they will continue to snuff out of existence, right in front of our very eyes! 
As Israel Falsely proclaims to be well within their rights to commit such atrocities! 
I ask , What has this world come to? To sit by and do nothing as such horrors continue to unfold right in front of our faces!
